definitions.definition: To draw air into ( inhale ), and expel air from ( exhale ), the lungs in order to extract oxygen and excrete waste gases.
To take in needed gases and expel waste gases in a similar way.
examples: Fish have gills so they can breathe underwater.

definitions.definition: To inhale (a gas) to sustain life.
examples: While life as we know it depends on oxygen, scientists have speculated that alien life forms might breathe chlorine or methane.
I will not allow it, as long as I still breathe .

definitions.definition: To draw something into the lungs.
examples: Try not to breathe too much smoke.

definitions.definition: To expel air from the lungs, exhale .
examples: If you breathe on a mirror, it will fog up.

definitions.definition: To exhale or expel (something) in the manner of breath .
examples: The flowers breathed a heady perfume.

definitions.definition: To give an impression of, to exude .
examples: The decor positively breathes classical elegance.
He breathed the words into her ear, but she understood them all.

definitions.definition: To pass like breath; noiselessly or gently; to emanate; to blow gently.
examples: The wind breathes through the trees.

definitions.label_groups: chiefly Evangelical and Charismatic Christianity , with God as agent

definitions.definition: To exchange gases with the environment.
examples: Garments made of certain new materials breathe well and keep the skin relatively dry during exercise.

definitions.definition: To rest ; to stop and catch one's breath.
To stop, to give ( a horse ) an opportunity to catch its breath.
examples: At higher altitudes you need to breathe your horse more often.

definitions.definition: To exercise ; to tire by brisk exercise.
To passionately devote much of one's life to (an activity, etc.).
examples: ―Do you like hiking? ―Are you kidding? I breathe hiking.

main_definition: ( intransitive ) To draw air into ( inhale ), and expel air from ( exhale ), the lungs in order to extract oxygen and excrete waste gases.
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive ) To take in needed gases and expel waste gases in a similar way.
( transitive ) To inhale (a gas) to sustain life.
( transitive ) To draw something into the lungs.
( intransitive ) To expel air from the lungs, exhale .
( transitive ) To exhale or expel (something) in the manner of breath .
( transitive ) To give an impression of, to exude .
To pass like breath; noiselessly or gently; to emanate; to blow gently.
( chiefly Evangelical and Charismatic Christianity , with God as agent ) To inspire ( scripture ).
( intransitive ) To exchange gases with the environment.
( intransitive , now rare ) To rest ; to stop and catch one's breath.
( transitive ) To stop, to give ( a horse ) an opportunity to catch its breath.
( transitive ) To exercise ; to tire by brisk exercise.
( transitive , figurative ) To passionately devote much of one's life to (an activity, etc.).
